desc.size: Medium-sized to large tree, 15 - 25 m tall, trunk diameter 0.8 - 1.4 m. One to four trunks; trunk often crooked. Crown broad, rounded, with upcurved main branches, spreading smaller branches, and drooping thinner shoots.

part.partText: brownish to dark gray, thick, smooth on young trees, becoming rough and furrowed into thick ridges.
slender, golden brown to olive-brown, smooth or with dense, silky hairs.
appressed against the stem (except end bud), yellow to yellowish brown, 2 mm long, cylindrical, curved, silky, downy, single bud scale; terminal bud absent.

alternate, with 3 - 6 mm long, silky, hairy, glandular leafstalks; bright green above, whitish or silvery beneath, 4 - 10 cm long, 1 - 2.5 cm wide, narrowly lanceolate to lanceolate, base tapering, tip pointed, margins finely toothed (6 - 10 per cm), teeth glandular, firm, silvery-silky when young, remaining silky beneath. In autumn the leaves turn yellow and drop late.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in slender, cylindrical, slightly upright catkins, 3 - 6 cm long on short, leafy stalks; scales greenish yellow, stamens 2, anthers yellow, ovary conical; insect- and wind-pollinated.
a capsule; in elongated clusters; basically stalkless, green to light brown, 5 mm long, flask-shaped, hairless; seeds with long, white, silky hairs attached; dispersed by wind and water.

similarSpecies.comments: Salix alba is distinguished from all other tree willows in the Chicago Region by having finely toothed leaves that are white-hairy beneath. Leaf margins are flat, not revolute (down-curved). Salix sericea, which has similar leaves, grows as a shrub.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Occasional along rivers, streams, lakes, and other wet sites, probably as an escape from cultivation.

notes.comments: Salix alba was introduced from Eurasia and is planted as a shade and ornamental tree. It can be attacked by a number of disease and insect problems, such as cankers, rusts, aphids, and galls. Its leaves, twigs, and branches often drop, leaving much litter beneath the tree.

etymology.comments: Salix is the Latin word for willow. Alba means white.
